citation.article-title: Isolation and description of Haloanaerobium praevalens gen. nov. and sp. nov., an obligately anaerobic halophile common to Great Salt Lake sediments.

p.s: Description of Haloanaerobium praevalens sp. nov.
Haloanaerobium praevalens (Prae va.'lens. L. adj. praevalens prevalent)
Cellular characteristics.
Straight rods approximately 1 x 2.4 μm, stain Gram-negative, and contains an outer wall membranous layer.
Nonmotile and nonsporing.
Colonies on agar plate are not pigmented.
DNA base composition of 27 ± 1 mol% G+C; cytochromes not detectable; catalase and oxidase negative.
Growth characteristics.
Optimum NaCl concentration for growth approximately 12.5%; no growth below 2% or above 30% salt.
Optimum temperature for growth is approximately 37°C maximum below 60°C minimum above 5°C pH range for growth; optimum 7.0-7.4, minimum ≥ 6.0, maximum ≤ 9.0, obligate halophile and anaerobe.
Complete growth inhibition by penicillin, tetracycline, cycloserine, or chloramphenicol (each at 100 μg/ml), sodium azide (500 μg/ml) or 02 (0.203 x 105 Pa).
Metabolic characteristics.
Chemoorganotroph.
Utilizes carbohydrates, pectin, amino acids, trypticase, and n-acetylglucosamine.
Major fermentation products of glucose are butyrate, acetate, propionate, H2, and CO2.
Methylmercaptan is produced from methionine degradation.
Sulfate, nitrate, and fumarate are not reduced.
Habitat.
Sediment and anoxic waters associated with hypersaline aquatic ecosystems.
Type strain GSL was isolated from 10 m bottom sediment in the South Arm of Great Salt Lake, Utah, USA.
The strain has been deposited in both the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen (DSM 2228) and the American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, MD, USA (ATCC 33744).
